title: 103_hr1078
content: The "Improved Immigration Law Enforcement Act of 1993" increases personnel levels of the Border Patrol to 6,600 full-time positions for fiscal year 1994. An additional $50,000,000 is authorized for equipment, support services, and training for the Border Patrol in fiscal year 1993. The Attorney General is required to provide inservice training for Border Patrol personnel to familiarize them with the rights and cultural backgrounds of individuals they encounter. $1,000,000 is authorized for this purpose in fiscal year 1994. The Attorney General is appropriated $1,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 for inservice training under the Immigration and Nationality Act, with funds authorized to remain available until expended. SEC. 5. INCREASE IN I.N.S. SUPPORT PERSONNEL. The number of full-time support positions for various departments within the Immigration and Naturalization Service shall be increased by 580 positions to support the increased personnel levels of the border patrol. SEC. 6. STRENGTHENED ENFORCEMENT OF WAGE AND HOUR LAWS. SEC. 6. STRENGTHENED ENFORCEMENT OF WAGE AND HOUR LAWS. The Wage and Hour Division of the Department of Labor will increase full-time positions by 250 for fiscal year 1994 to investigate violations of wage and hour laws in areas with high concentrations of undocumented aliens. SEC. 7. STRENGTHENED ENFORCEMENT OF EMPLOYER SANCTIONS. The Investigations Division of the Immigration and Naturalization Service will increase positions by 250 in fiscal year 1994 to investigate violations of employer sanctions provisions. Individuals will be assigned to investigate violations of section 274A of the Immigration and Nationality Act. SEC. 8. INCREASED NUMBER OF ASSISTANT UNITED STATES ATTORNEYS. The Department of Justice will hire 21 more Assistant United States Attorneys in fiscal year 1994. These positions will be dedicated to prosecuting individuals involved in illegal alien smuggling, fraud, and other related crimes. Subsection 274(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to increase the penalty for offenses involving 5 or more aliens, other criminal activity, exploitation of minors, or dangerous and inhumane actions. The penalty for offenses involving dangerous or inhumane treatment, serious bodily injury, or death of an alien is increased under an amendment to Subsection 274(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act. SEC. 10 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to increase penalties for bringing in aliens. The mere employment of an individual does not constitute harboring. SEC. 11 involves negotiations with Mexico and Canada. SEC. 11 of the Immigration and Nationality Act calls for discussions with Mexico and Canada to establish programs to prevent and prosecute the smuggling of undocumented aliens into the United States. The Attorney General, in conjunction with the Secretary of State, should lead these efforts, with a focus on deterring and prosecuting those involved in organized smuggling. A progress report on these programs is required within one year of the Act's enactment.
